poem:
"An Echo in the Hebrides"

In the silence of the castle, nitid atop Harris,
Ghostly secrets waltz on cobwebbed chandeliers.
Murder cries into the gilded light, a scream
piercing the placid Hebridean night,
A storm of drama landing where songs of gulls are sparse.
Oh, how easily tranquility shatters, 
Still, the sedated seas speak your taciturn truths,
Unrevealed yet, beneath glowering Gaelic skies.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "An t-Eilean: £1m-an-episode drama to bring Outer Hebrides to global audience The tranquility of a remote castle in the Outer Hebrides, with its views of long golden beaches, rocky coasts and glowering skies, is about to be shattered by the staging of a woman’s murder. Detectives will fly in from Inverness. The drama will catapult the castle and this secluded Gaelic-speaking corner of Harris to a global audience, as a dysfunctional family’s long-buried secrets emerge.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
